lexUnit.name: vent.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: give free expression to (a strong emotion)

sentence.text: Soon he would need to vent the anger she felt already gathering , and she was the nearest person .
He described to me a life of violence and hatred in which he lost no opportunity to vent his anger upon those around him -- and , what is more , he actually enjoyed doing so .
It was Joe 's attitude of total submission that prevented Tom from venting his anger on him there and then .
LESBIAN and gay delegates yesterday vented their anger at an attempt by the Labour leadership to abandon past conference calls to reduce the age of consent for homosexual acts from 21 to 16 .
FLASHPOINT : Howard Wilkinson vents his anger from the touchline
After being repelled by police , the crowd vented its anger by damaging property and overturning police cars .
Other drivers , unhappy with their jobs , often vent frustration on their cars
How satisfying it would have been to vent her feelings in one sharp slap of that carved-ivory face !
Spectators at club matches in New Zealand have vented their feelings in no uncertain fashion , jeering every time the action stops and their side loses the ball .
The overt and crudest manifestations of Irish misogyny were our first target and we vented our rage and flexed our lesbian muscles in a myriad of dangerous and daring ways .
Yesterday they vented their wrath in a letter to the Times .
Where it was still highly risky and dangerous to speak negatively of the FÃ¼hrer , people frequently vented their wrath on the Party and its representatives .
Do you think you can vent your temper on me just as you please ?
